The patient has symptoms of otitis media with bulging tympanic membrane, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae. Given the patient’s history of atopic dermatitis and urticaria, topical hydrocortisone should be avoided as it can worsen the infection and gentamicin can cause ototoxicity. Otic ofloxacin can be used, but oral antibiotics are preferred for more severe cases. Tympanocentesis is not recommended as it is invasive and not routinely done in uncomplicated cases. Oral azithromycin is the most appropriate choice as it covers both S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae, and it is often used as a first-line agent in cases of acute otitis media.
